frames.title: S001. About Scott Electric and Welcome to Training

choices.label: Go to Quote to Cash Work Flow At SE Electrical Distribution

frames.narr1: Slide S001. About Scott Electric and Welcome to Training-  About Scott Electric and Welcome to Training.
frames.narr2: About Scott Electric and Welcome to Training.
frames.narr3:
S001. About Scott Electric and Welcome to Training  Scott Electric is a leading independent wholesale electrical distributor, serving electrical, mechanical, and general contractors, industrial customers, government agencies, and retail partners. The company provides a broad range of electrical products, lighting, tools, and related services to support both day-to-day operations and long-term projects. Welcome to the Scott Electric Training Site
Welcome to the Scott Electric Training Site. This platform is designed to help you build the knowledge and skills needed to support our customers safely, accurately, and efficiently. Here you will find guided learning, reference materials, and role-based courses aligned with how we work every day  in sales, operations, service, administration, and support.
Thank you for investing your time in training. Your commitment to learning and improvement is an important part of keeping Scott Electric strong, responsive, and customer-focused.

Quote to Cash Work Flow At SE Electrical Distribution  This site is a typical Quote to cache representation in what is called a workflow This outlines the various steps performed by various swim lanes if you will or functional groups and provides a overall picture of how we end up serving our customers and continuing to keep our creed of customer comes first

frames.title: S003. Pictorial representation of Quote to Cash - At SE Electrical Distribution

frames.narr3: S003. Pictorial representation of Quote to Cash - At SE Electrical Distribution  This slide is aptly named The Pictorial Representation of Quote to Cash at Scott Electric the distribution business While this light is the precursor to the focused area of Quote to cache the picture shows how the various phases within that task is directly or indirectly affecting other components within the system for example an inventory is consumed the inventory has to be replenished and that is done by the procure to pay cycle Similarly because a sales occurred there has to be accounting for the sale and also at the end of the day collection of the payment against the invoice so hence that goes into the financial side of the impact now because inventory is being both consumed replenished and in some cases being procured and directly shipped to the customer that has a direct impact on how the inventory is managed within the system

frames.title: M1. Sales Order Line Entry - At SE Electrical Distribution

choices.label: Go to A decision on whether the user want to enter lines using "Easy" entry

frames.narr1: Slide M1. Sales Order Line Entry-  Sales Order Line Entry.
frames.narr3: M1. Sales Order Line Entry - At SE Electrical Distribution  Use these instructions to enter a Stock Order (SO) for a customer. Select Sales > Entry > Order. Select Stock Order in the Order Type field. Complete the remaining fields on the page, and then click Next. Add line items. See Line entry modes. Click Taxes and Totals. Verify or complete the tax information. Apply any discounts or addons. Click Recalculate to update the order total. Optionally, click Freight Rate Shop to view shipping options. Click Collect Payment. Complete the payment information. If you are accepting a cash, check, or credit card payment, verify the journal settings and then click OK. Click Save to complete the order.

frames.title: Y1. User has selected Easy entry - At SE Electrical Distribution

choices.label: Go to Easy Line entry Selected

frames.narr1: Slide Y1. User has selected Easy entry-  User has selected Easy entry.
frames.narr3: Y1. User has selected Easy entry  User has opted to use the easy line entry Easy Use this mode to conduct a global search for a product. You can use values such as cross-reference values and the product description to search a product. You can add a single line item or multiple line items to the order in this mode. If you specify a price before dropping the line to the grid, it is treated as a price override. The price that is entered is used regardless of what is set up on the Product Setup or Product Warehouse Product Setup record. Note: Pricing logic is not initiated when you select products in Easy Line Entry mode. If you use PD Pricing Setup records to set pricing and discounts for most of your products, you can enable alerts about products with associated PD records. Select the Check for Non-Standard Products in Easy and Quick Line Entry option in Sales Order Entry-Order Entry Defaults.

You can use values such as cross-reference values and the product description to search a product. You can add a single line item or multiple line items to the order in this mode. If you specify a price before dropping the line to the grid, it is treated as a price override. The price that is entered is used regardless of what is set up on the Product Setup or Product Warehouse Product Setup record. Note: Pricing logic is not initiated when you select products in Easy Line Entry mode. You can select Check for Non-Standard Products in Easy and Quick Line Entry in Sales Order Entry-Order Entry Defaults to receive alerts about promotional products that are set up in PD Pricing Setup and other non-standard and restricted products. Hold your mouse over the warning or error icon to view messages. You cannot add products with errors to the order.

frames.title: S5. Shopping List Entry - At SE Electrical Distribution

choices.label: Go to select shopping list type

frames.narr1: Slide S5. Shopping List Entry-  Shopping List Entry.
frames.narr3: S5. Shopping List Entry  ou can access the Shopping List feature from Line Entry menu in Sales Order Entry-Select Products. You can create a Shopping List that is based on promotional products, past sales, previous orders, product lists, and Infor CPQ product configurations. Promotional products are based on pricing records in PD Pricing Setup. Past sales and previous orders are based on the customer's transaction history. Product lists are set up in Product List Setup. Product lists are often used to sell slow-moving products or overstocked products. Products configured in CPQ can be returned as individual shopping list components. Use the Shopping List function to perform these actions: Select products from a customerâ€™s ordering history within a month/year range. Select products that are listed in the ordering history and automatically batch load the products into the sales order as separate line items. Select products from a list of specific previous orders or from a specific product list. Use the Shopping List to show a list with these elements: All of the products a customer has ordered in the last two months The last quantity ordered for each product The last price that was given for each product Past sales totals for products by month You can select individual products from the Shopping List to add to the order, or add all products from the Shopping List to the order. You can change the quantity to order for each product.

frames.title: S6. select shopping list type - At SE Electrical Distribution

choices.label: Go to Enter List Criteria

frames.narr1: Slide S6. select shopping list type-  select shopping list type.
frames.narr3: S6. select shopping list type  Promotional Products shopping list Promotional products are products that are on sale at a special price or discount for a limited time. Promotional pricing records are set up in PD Pricing Setup at either the product or product price type level. When you add the product to the customerâ€™s order, the price is obtained from PD Pricing Setup. The promotional price is then charged to the customer. You can view pricing detail in the Pricing view in the Add Line Item section of Sales Order Entry. To view all current promotions, select the Shopping List option and then click Promotional Products. Recalling a large number of records can affect your systemâ€™s performance. To minimize the number of records to sort through, specify the maximum number of records to display. You can also filter the records that are displayed in Customer Order Pad Filter Setup to view only specific customers, customer types, and product categories. When filters are defined, those particular records are not displayed in the Shopping List. When you select to automatically launch this style, each time the Shopping List is accessed, promotional pricing is launched. If you clear the Automatically Launch This Style option, you can select from the different styles available. Past Sales shopping list You can select products from a list of products that the customer has purchased previously by selecting Past Sales. Specify a range of months and the number of product records to recall for the Shopping List. You can also include past sales for these types of products: Nonstocks products Products that were sold from the warehouse on the order to the customer on the order and the customer's ship tos. Products that were sold to the customer or ship to on the order from any warehouse. The recommended quantity for the products in the Shopping List is based on the first order found. To see past sales information as monthly totals, use the Past Sales window. Previous Orders shopping list Customers often order the same product repeatedly, or duplicate entire orders. The Previous Orders function lets you import product from up to 10 past orders into the current Shopping List. These orders can originate from any customer account. Because your pricing might have changed since the original order was shipped, you can have the system re-price the products or retain the original pricing. The recommended quantity is based on the first order found. Product List shopping list Product lists are user-defined lists of product set up in Product List Setup. Sales personnel or inbound call centers use these lists primarily to promote product sales on slow-moving products or overstocked products to their customers. If you use a Product List, select the Product List Type and specify the number of products you want to recall. The product list is then moved into your current Shopping List. The recommended quantity is based on the product list.

frames.title: S7. Enter List Criteria - At SE Electrical Distribution

choices.label: Go to Enter Quantity

frames.narr1: Slide S7. Enter List Criteria-  Enter List Criteria.
frames.narr3: S7. Enter List Criteria  The ordering history information is from the SM Extended Totals Warehouse/Product by Customer Report. The information contained in this file is automatically updated each time Sales Entry Processing Invoice Processing Report is generated, if the Customer, Product Category by Warehouse options are selected in SA Administrator Options-Sales History-Levels. The Update Sales Manager option must also be selected in Sales Entry Processing Invoice Processing Report. You can filter the ordering history information by setting up records in Customer Order Pad Filter Setup for specific customers or customer types and product categories. When you set up a customer or customer type with product categories in Customer Order Pad Filter Setup, those product categories are not displayed when you use the Shopping List.

frames.title: S15. Advanced line entry selected - At SE Electrical Distribution

choices.label: Go to Enter Product Info

frames.narr1: Slide S15. Advanced line entry selected-  Advanced line entry selected.
frames.narr3: S15. Advanced line entry selected  Advanced Use this mode to add a single line item to the order. In this mode, you can specify additional information that may be required for processing, such as sourcing, serial or lot number assignment, or pricing changes. Values for the line item that may differ from the order, such as Promise Date and Rush status, are available in the Extended Fields section. You can also use this mode to add a printed or internal comment to the line. All line entry modes in Sales Order Entry are available, with these exceptions: On Correction orders, only the Advanced and Return Multiple modes are available. On Direct Orders,only the Advanced mode is available. If you specify a product on a line and click Finish before you add the line to the order, these events occur: The line is added to the order. The order is completed.

frames.narr1: Slide S19. Create Add Kit Components-  Create Add Kit Components.
frames.narr3: S19. Create Add Kit Components  In Sales Order Entry, you can source single or multiple components for build-on-demand (BOD) or nonstock kits. You can tie a stock or nonstock component line to a purchase order or warehouse transfer, including a direct order. If a component of the prebuilt kit is another prebuilt kit, then you can tie the component kit to a work order. Kit component sourcing is initiated on the Kits page in Advanced Line Entry. You can source one or more components from the Multi-Comp Sourcing page. You can also source a component when you add a component to a kit. If you create a fabricated kit in Sales Order Entry, then you must source the components in KP Work Order Center Entry. Ties are only created if the quantity ordered is less than the quantity reserved. To create a tie for a component that has the full quantity reserved, add the kit to the sales order without sourcing the component. Then, in the Kit Details section for the component, change the reserved amount for component to less than the quantity needed before creating the tie. The tie is created for the quantity ordered less the quantity reserved. Note: You cannot delete a component that is tied to a source document from a sales order. Use these instructions to create a tie for one or more components: Create a stock order. In Advanced Line Entry, specify the BOD or nonstock kit in the Product field, and then specify the quantity. Click Kits. Select one or more components to tie to a sourcing document, and then click Multi-Comp Sourcing. Specify the product source. Complete the remaining fields for the selected product source. When you are sourcing a single component, the ARP vendor or warehouse is displayed. When you are sourcing multiple components, the ARP vendor or warehouse is not displayed because the ARP for each component can be different. Click Submit, and then click the left arrow to return to Advanced Line Entry. Click Add to add the line to the order. . Finish the order.

frames.title: S21. Confirm Pricing - At SE Electrical Distribution

choices.label: Go to Add lines to sales order

frames.narr1: Slide S21. Confirm Pricing-  Confirm Pricing.
frames.narr3: S21. Confirm Pricing  Selling products for highest price paid If a customer places an order for a product and has historically paid a higher price than the price that defaults in Sales Order Entry, you can set system options to force the higher price for that product and customer. This ensures that the customer is not offered the product at a price less than they are accustomed to paying, and you receive the highest margin on the sale. This may also encourage customers to agree to a contract price to receive a better price in the future. To implement the Highest Price Paid pricing search, you must set two options in SA Administrator Options-Documents-Sales Orders: Months History and Exclude Level 2. These options define the number of months of sales history to search for the highest price, and whether to exclude Price Type Level 2 sales in the search. The Highest Price Paid search is not conducted if the original default price was determined using a contract price. A contract price is a Price Type level 1 (Customer/Product) PD Pricing Setup record. The contract price is not changed by the Highest Price Paid search. Additionally, if you use Price Type level 2 pricing records (Cust/Prod Price Type, Cust/Prod Line, Cust/Prod Cat, or Cust/Rebate Type), and the Exclude Level 2 option is selected, any prices that originally default on the sales order line using level 2 pricing records are not overridden by the highest price paid. If you use promotional pricing, you still have the option to choose between the promotional price and non-promotional price. The non-promotional price reflects the highest price, if it applies. If you do not have permission to select a promotional price (the Access Promo Price in OE option in SA Operator Setup-Entry Options is not selected), the Promo Price Default selection in SA Administrator Options-Documents-Sales Orders determines the price to use: Lowest, Promo, or Regular. This automatic selection may result in the promo price instead of the highest price being selected. You can override contractual level pricing with multiple level price search. This pricing search can conflict with the Highest Price Paid search. We recommend you select one method or the other, not both. When a sales order line price is replaced with a higher price by this search, the order number, suffix, and line number are stored on the new order line. In addition, the Price Origin Code is set to â€œHâ€. This code is displayed in Sales Order Inquiry and Sales Customer Pricing Inquiry. To prevent the highest price search in Sales Customer Pricing Inquiry, select Return/Ignore Highest Price. Run the Sales Order Master List Report to see the Highest Price Order and Line that affected the Highest Price calculation. This is printed under the Original System Line Data section.

frames.narr3: S21. Confirm Pricing  Selling products for highest price paid If a customer places an order for a product and has historically paid a higher price than the price that defaults in Sales Order Entry, you can set system options to force the higher price for that product and customer. This ensures that the customer is not offered the product at a price less than they are accustomed to paying, and you receive the highest margin on the sale. This may also encourage customers to agree to a contract price to receive a better price in the future. To implement the Highest Price Paid pricing search, you must set two options in SA Administrator Options-Documents-Sales Orders: Months History and Exclude Level 2. These options define the number of months of sales history to search for the highest price, and whether to exclude Price Type Level 2 sales in the search. The Highest Price Paid search is not conducted if the original default price was determined using a contract price. A contract price is a Price Type level 1 (Customer/Product) PD Pricing Setup record. The contract price is not changed by the Highest Price Paid search. Additionally, if you use Price Type level 2 pricing records (Cust/Prod Price Type, Cust/Prod Line, Cust/Prod Cat, or Cust/Rebate Type), and the Exclude Level 2 option is selected, any prices that originally default on the sales order line using level 2 pricing records are not overridden by the highest price paid. If you use promotional pricing, you still have the option to choose between the promotional price and non-promotional price. The non-promotional price reflects the highest price, if it applies. If you do not have permission to select a promotional price (the Access Promo Price in OE option in SA Operator Setup-Entry Options is not selected), the Promo Price Default selection in SA Administrator Options-Documents-Sales Orders determines the price to use: Lowest, Promo, or Regular. This automatic selection may result in the promo price instead of the highest price being selected. You can override contractual level pricing with multiple level price search. This pricing search can conflict with the Highest Price Paid search. We recommend you select one method or the other, not both. When a sales order line price is replaced with a higher price by this search, the order number, suffix, and line number are stored on the new order line. In addition, the Price Origin Code is set to â€œHâ€. This code is displayed in Sales Order Inquiry and Sales Customer Pricing Inquiry. To prevent the highest price search in Sales Customer Pricing Inquiry, select Return/Ignore Highest Price. Run the Sales Order Master List Report to see the Highest Price Order and Line that affected the Highest Price calculation. This is printed under the Original System Line Data section.
